author: yorickdowne
content:
No, EF really has not pushed the Pi4 as the recommended device. Joe at RocketPool was keen on the Pi4 for a while, but now considers it too restrictive, too hard to make work. He‚Äôs moved on to Rock5 B. 
The bulk of solo stakers use a NUC or miniPC of some sort. Some build a home server instead, with a SuperMicro or AsRock Rack board, some buy a miniPC from dAppNode with turnkey software, and some use dedicated servers with hosting services.

author: yorickdowne
content: There‚Äôs a small number of Windows PCs and macs. Those usually have a harder time because the bulk of the testing and documentation is Linux based, particularly Debian and derivatives.

author: alexssd7fp
content:
> tornado transactions are so rare impact on total mining profits would be basically zero, leaving ideology as the only possible factor to switch. Switching is manual work and miners are least likely to care of everyone.
It's one click basically.

> Solo mining would be purely ideological because there were no mev relays, making it a loss making move, and in the long run literally impossible - because difficulty slowly rises to a level in which most efficient miners are the only ones making a tiny profit, which includes mev profits.
This is a good argument, although if you are large enough you could get connected to Flashbots.

> Legally pools are inherently public entities, making them much easier to attack than anonymous solo validator somewhere. This means that a situation in which all pools censor was a likely outcome, and there would be literally nothing to be done about it while keeping PoW.
You'd have to be based in the US to be forced to comply with their sanctions. And funnily, the share of American ETH pools was 0% back when Ethereum was powered by PoW.

author: yorickdowne
content:
There are still people happily running their Pi4. That requires Nimbus and Geth with reduced cache, and there is one (1) known SSD model that works, and ... it can be done, people are still doing it, and they are having fun.

I wouldn't recommend it to someone new. That's hard mode.
